questions.text: A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023) FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is bitten by a scorpion. Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom by counteracting the severe cardiovascular and systemic effects induced by the venom.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: As per the latest biomedical waste management guidelines in India, the following combination is incorrect? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blue container – Incineration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blue containers for biomedical waste should not be incinerated but treated and then recycled as per the guidelines.

questions.text: What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023) Pulmonary Aortic Mitral
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 22%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%. Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds. Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.
  • • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds. Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).

questions.text: Calculate Maternal Mortality Ratio in a population of 2 lacs, with 4000 live births, Death were 4 by PPH, 2 deaths by electrocution, 2 deaths by sepsis, 2 deaths by abortion, 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, and 5 still births. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 250 per 1 lac

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.
  • • Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days of delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.
  • • In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:
  • • In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:
  • • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) 2 deaths by sepsis 2 deaths by abortion 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy
  • • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • • 2 deaths by sepsis
  • • 2 deaths by abortion
  • • 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy
  • • These deaths should be included in the calculation as they are related to maternity or its complications.
  • • The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included in the calculation of MMR.
  • • The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included
  • • Therefore, the total number of maternal deaths is 10 (4 + 2 + 2 + 2).
  • • The number of live births is given as 4,000.
  • • MMR = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000
  • • = (10 / 4,000) × 100,000
  • • = 250 per 1,00,000 live births

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths (deaths related to maternity or its complications) by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate

options.label: B
options.text: Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.correct_answer: B. Pupils accommodate but do not react
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4-8%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is estimated to be around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population risk of approximately 2-4%.

questions.text: Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in which type of dementia? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dementia with lewy body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capgras syndrome, a delusion of misidentification where a patient believes a familiar person has been replaced by an identical impostor, is most commonly seen in dementia with Lewy bodies, followed by Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with sudden severe headache. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SAH presents with sudden, severe headache and is identified on CT by hyperdensity in the CSF cisterns. The most common cause is aneurysmal rupture, best evaluated using CT angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.
  • • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score: Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) Fetal movements Fetal tone Fetal breathing movements A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention. Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components: Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid index (AFI)
  • • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score: Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) Fetal movements Fetal tone Fetal breathing movements
  • • Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid volume (AFV) Fetal movements Fetal tone Fetal breathing movements
  • • Non-stress test (NST)
  • • Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
  • • Fetal movements
  • • Fetal tone
  • • Fetal breathing movements
  • • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components: Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid index (AFI)
  • • Non-stress test (NST) Amniotic fluid index (AFI)
  • • Non-stress test (NST)
  • • Amniotic fluid index (AFI)
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Amniotic fluid volume : Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.
  • • Option A. Amniotic fluid volume
  • • Option B. Fetal tone : Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.
  • • Option B. Fetal tone
  • • Option D. Non-stress test : Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.
  • • Option D. Non-stress test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 122
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 122

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

questions.text: G2 at 8 weeks diagnosed to have hyperthyroidism. What is the drug of choice? (NEET PG 2024)

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues .
  • ➤ Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 400 mEq

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sodium deficit can be calculated using the formula:
  • • Sodium Deficit=Total Body Water×(Desired Sodium−Actual Sodium)
  • • For females, the Total Body Water (TBW) is 50% of body weight
  • • TBW=0.5×Body Weight
  • • Here, the body weight is 40 kg:
  • • TBW=0.5×40 kg=20 LTBW=0.5×40 kg=20 L
  • • The desired sodium concentration is 140 mEq/L and the actual sodium concentration is 120
  • • mEq/L:
  • • Sodium Deficit=20 L×(140 mEq/L−120 mEq/L) =400 mEq
  • • Therefore, the sodium deficit is 400 mEq.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ The sodium deficit for a female weighing 40 kg with a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L, aiming for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L, is 400 mEq.

questions.text: Key feature of depression? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low mood

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low mood, or sadness of mood, is the key defining feature of depression, as depression is primarily a mood disorder.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Togavirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.
  • • Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma):
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma:
  • • Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.
  • • Option D. Renal cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ There are three isoforms of NOS iNOS- inducible nNOS - neuronal eNOS- endothelial

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16: Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.
  • • Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.
  • • Option B. Increase tidal volume:
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.
  • • Option C. Reduce respiratory rate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule is a key white matter structure that lies between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus, transmitting important motor and sensory pathways to the cerebral cortex.
